awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Metal-Free Catalysts for Oxygen Evolution and Oxygen Reduction Reactions: From Molecular Models to Graphene-Based Electrocatalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
The sun delivers a large amount of energy to our planet in the form of sunlight. A very small fraction of this solar energy is sufficient to satisfy our energy demands. However, to use the sun's energy efficiently, ways to "bottle" the energy from the sun into a chemical form of solar fuel need to be developed. One approach to creating solar fuels is to split water into gaseous hydrogen and oxygen molecules.  This water splitting process needs "helper" molecules, or catalysts, to occur rapidly and efficiently. When energy is needed, the hydrogen and oxygen can then be recombined in a device known as a fuel cell to produce electricity on demand. Unfortunately, the current chemical reactions that converts water into oxygen (the oxygen-evolving reaction, or OER) and oxygen back into water (the oxygen reduction reaction, or ORR) are too slow and inefficient to be a competitive replacement for fossil fuels.  Chemists have yet to discover practical catalysts that can accelerate these processes. In this award, Dr. Ksenjia Glusac of Bowling Green State University is investigating catalysts that not only accelerate OER and ORR, but also are inexpensive and non-toxic. Her model catalysts are made of earth-abundant elements, such as carbon and nitrogen, and utilize the high conductivity of graphene, a building block material of graphite found in pencils. The project also includes outreach activities that aim at introducing energy-related topics into K-12, college and general public education. Raising public energy literacy is a necessary step towards allowing informed decision-making on energy-related behaviors and policies.

The oxygen evolving reaction (OER) and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) are key processes occurring in solar water splitting devices, fuel cells and metal-air batteries. The high conductivity of graphene, coupled with the catalytic performance of nitrogen sites makes N-doped graphenic materials excellent candidates for metal-free OER/ORR catalysis. However, the mechanistic understanding of catalysis by N-doped materials is limited, inhibiting the development of a new generation of materials with improved performance. In this project, Dr. Ksenjia Glusac of Bowling Green State University is supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program to investigate molecular model catalysts of N-doped carbon materials, with the goal of pinpointing the ideal structural motifs that lead to efficient OER and ORR catalysis. Particular emphasis is placed on structures that lead to reversible (bifunctional) OER/ORR catalysis because the electrocatalytic reversibility is directly linked to the decrease in the overpotential of the catalyzed reaction, resulting in greater catalytic efficiency. Dr. Glusac's research results allow her to obtain mechanistic insights into electrocatalytic OER/ORR by N-doped structures and develop a chemical methodology for implementing effective molecular motifs into graphenic materials. Furthermore, broader societal impacts result from activities in the Glusac laboratory that focus on implementing energy-related topics into K-12, college and public education. Raising public energy literacy is a necessary step towards allowing informed decision-making on energy-related behaviors and policies by the general public.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Proposal title: SusChem: Metal-Free Catalysts for Oxygen Evolution and Oxygen Reduction Reactions: From Molecular Models to Graphene-Based Electrocatalysts

Proposal number: 1806388

Total amount funded: $560,000

Funding period: 09/01/2017 – 07/31/2020

 

This project explored the catalysts that accelerate reactions relevant for the interconversion between electric and chemical energy. In specific, we investigated the interconversion between water and molecular oxygen, a reaction that is critical for the utilization of green hydrogen. This reaction is particularly challenging to catalyze and often requires the use of expensive and rare transition metal catalysts. We investigated the use of metal-free motifs for this conversion and found that these inexpensive catalysts accelerate the electrochemical oxidation of water to oxygen. Our discovery is relevant to the applications in water splitting, a process that uses solar, wind or other renewable forms of energy to generate hydrogen fuel from water. The intellectual merit of this work is associated with a discovery of co-catalytic approaches to electrocatalysis. We found that the complex electrochemical transformation from water to oxygen can be efficiently accelerated by using synergic activity of two types of catalysts: the electrode surface serving as a heterogeneous co-catalyst and the dissolved molecule in the electrolyte solution serving as a homogeneous co-catalyst. Our approach provides more “knobs to turn”: the chemistry of each co-catalyst can be independently modified to fine-tune the catalytic performance.

 

The project also investigated the use of conductive carbon materials for energy conversion applications. Conductive nanocarbons, such as graphene, carbon nanotubes and other porous carbons are often used as materials in batteries and other applications requiring electronically conductive and inexpensive building blocks. However, they are inefficient catalyst for electrochemical transformations because they are too inert. To convert these materials into efficient catalysts for energy conversion applications, we investigated methods to functionalize these materials with chemically tunable molecular functional groups. We found that nanocarbons can be efficiently functionalized using chemical bonding or intermolecular interactions to form novel hybrid materials that can use electrical or radiant input energy to drive target chemical transformations. Our work is of significant relevance to the scientific community exploring a wide range of electrochemical and photochemical transformations, since it provides methods for combining catalysts with electronically conductive or light-absorbing moieties.

 

The results of this project were published in peer-reviewed journal articles and PhD theses. Our work was also shared with the scientific community in the form of conference presentations and departmental seminars by the PI and PhD students. Furthermore, the funds were used to train postdoctoral fellows, PhD students and undergraduate students in the area of electrochemistry and spectroscopy. Furthermore, the team members have performed a number of outreach activities involving local K-12 institutions: we  visited local elementary schools to provide hands-on lectures on light and its interaction with matter and we participated as supervisors in local Science Olympiads, where we worked with high school students on the assignments involving chemistry and spatial skills.

 


Last Modified: 05/16/2023
Modified by: Ksenija D Glusac
